description.text:
This "whisk vessel" can be used for whipping cream, eggs, or anything else you may want to whip with a whisk. At first, I wanted to build a cup that would keep liquids from splashing out when I whisk them, but, as the design was morphing closer to a two-part dish that almost fully enclosed the whisk, I realized that I can build the whisk into the vessel.
The idea is, you put the food into the "inner" part (the one with threads on the outside), put the whisk grid on top (it has a ledge around the perimeter that fits into the dish and keeps the grid from sliding sideways), screw the outer part over it, tight, and shake the whole thing for a while. I tried whipping eggs for an omelet, and some cream, it works.

The most important detail here is a choice of the filament. There are food-safe filaments, I used Taulman Tech-G. A clear PETG or clear PLA would probably be OK (PETG handles heat better). For colored filaments, you need to know if the coloring is food-safe.

Printing is straightforward, see printing notes. After printing you may need to sand the inside with a fine sandpaper to make it smooth.

This is a simple bracket for mounting a Laser Christmas Light from laserchristmaslights.com. In recent years, they started supplying a bracket for mounting to walls/poles/trees, but our older version did not have one. This allows you to get maximum house coverage, while avoiding firing lasers into the sky that might affect planes.

The tolerances are tricky on this print, so I made them a bit more forgiving. This should allow you to print at larger layers heights and still get a reasonable fit. I suggest printing this solid with 100% infill for a stronger part, as this will be exposed to the elements and bear a not insignificant weight.

author: LindseyOwn

description.text: Alrighty guys! This post contains a project that I have been working on for a good year. I am a huge Harry Potter fan, and one day I had the idea: "Why don't I print my Pottermore wand?" I found all of the different combinations of the wands you can get, and made a 3D model for each. The models are fairly basic, but that is on purpose. Print this in wood PLA filament, and it feels just like a real wand. It is recommended that you finish the wands with paint, as I have done. All models are dimensioned off the pictures on Pottermore within .01 in.

description.header: How do I print my wand?
description.text:
Step 1: Getting your Pottermore wand

If you have your Pottermore wand already, skip this step and move on to the next section

To get a personalized wand, first go to www.pottermore.com

Then, click Login in the top right corner, and proceed through the signup instructions.

Once you have an account, go to my.pottermore.com/user-profile if you are there not already

Scroll to the bottom of the page and follow the survey for getting a wand.

Now, move on to the next step

Step 2: Picking your files

Here's where things get more interesting...

Go to my.pottermore.com/user-profile/wand

Right-click on the image of your wand, and (left) click on save image as

Now, you will see a name in save box that goes something like "wand-[COLOR]-[LENGTH]-[HANDLE].png"
(For example, mine is "wand-yellow-quite_long-ball_handle.png")

What we care about is the [LENGTH] and [HANDLE] portions. Refer to the following tables for the correct files:

Stick:
0 = Very Short
1 = Quite Short
2 = Average
3 = Quite Long
4 = Very Long

Handle:
A = Rope
B = Ball
C = Carved
(Example: for my wand, "wand-yellow-quite_long-ball_handle.png, " my files are "B_Handle and "3_Stick"

You now have your files! Wahoo!

Step 3: Scaling (Optional)

This is where you go for accuracy, but it ain't necessary.

These are the default lengths for all wand combinations (in inches, because USA!):

A0: 10.08
A1: 11.23
A2: 12.07
A3: 12.86
A4: 14.08
B0: 10.3
B1: 11.45
B2: 12.29
B3: 13.08
B4: 14.3
C0: 10.45
C1: 11.6
C2: 12.44
C3: 13.23
C4: 14.45

(Letters are for handles, numbers are for sticks)

Now take your wand length as stated here (my.pottermore.com/user-profile/wand) and divide that number by the default number to get your multiplier. In your printing configurator (Slic3d, Cura, etc.), scale both pieces by this number.

(Ex: My wand is 13" in length, and a B3 so, 13/13.08 = 0.9939 = 99%)

Step 4: Printing time!

Printing is actually pretty flexible, with many materials.
I have used ABS, PLA, ABS Clear and PLA wood, with all being a success.
Use the print temps for whatever material you want.
Print the handle with the hole for the stick up.
Print the stick on a long side, as it gives the effect of grain in wood.
Resolution should be .2 mm or finer.
Supports on (80° works for me).
Raft if you want.
Infill of 20% or higher.

Step 5: Post-print

Sand, paint, and do what you want!

If you want instructions on how I painted my wands, leave a comment and I will add the instructions on to this post

Step 6: You're done!

Now indulge on the product of my obsessive nerdiness and your creativity!

Tell me if I need to fix anything, or if you want me to add something for a V2?

Also, post pictures of the wands you made!

title: Articulating, Wall-Mounted, Magnetic Phone Mount Rotated Arm

description.text:
Liked the articulating arm, but needed a way to rotate the connector 90 degrees from the previous one so I modeled this up.

Really I wanted to twist the arm braces but my modeling program is not that capable. I wanted strength so I dropped a sphere right in between the arm braces and adjusted it to look good and retain high strength.

Part of the need for this was because my remixed phone/tablet mount (seen in last photo) from [https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194278 ] where I added a mount brace to would only go in the rotated orientation when holding the tablet in portrait mode.

If anyone is interested in the tablet mount let me know and I'll look into making it available. That model works well for now, but needs more work before sharing.

UPDATE: Added a slightly longer one that gives 1 more tick of rotation. Haven't printed it yet, but there is no reason it shouldn't work just as good as this one.

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

No

Yes

0.2

30

Notes:

1.2mm walls. Supports to bed only.

Took the short Arm and cut it in half(actually more like 70%) Then duplicated, spun around to overlap with original, then rotated 90 degrees so it made an arm that connected 90 degrees rotated from where it started.

Really wanted to twist the arm braces but my modeling program is not that capable. I wanted strength so I dropped a sphere right in between the arm braces and took the corners off so it more smoothly connected to the sphere.

Came out pretty good. Works well for me.

title: Cessna 172 Flight Simulator Panel - 5-Position Key Switch

description.text:
A bracket for assembling a 5-position, spring-return, key switch for a Cessna 172 flight simulator panel.

For more information, see the project details at https://cessna172sim.allanglen.com.

For details about this part, see https://cessna172sim.allanglen.com/docs/key-switch/.
For a complete parts list, refer to https://cessna172sim.allanglen.com/docs/key-switch/#parts-list

Some modifications must be made to the cabinet lock to allow the shaft of the rotary encoder to be securely attached:

  1. Drill out the screw hole in the cabinet lock body to allow the shaft of the rotary encoder to be inserted snugly into the body of the lock. A washer or two may be needed to ensure the bar on the cabinet lock is securely pressed against the square mount on the cabinet lock body.
  2. Drill a hole in the side of the cabinet lock body and tap it to allow a hex set screw to be secured against the rotary encoder shaft. A hole must also be made in the cabinet lock barrel to allow access to the set screw
  3. Remove the rotational stop from the cabinet lock barrel. This design uses the stops of the rotary switch instead.
The five positions of the key switch. The last position (START) is spring loaded and returns to BOTH when released.
This thing is part of the Cessna 172 Flight Simulator Panel collection.

description.text:
I use these indicators to determine the ideal print temperature and flowrate for new rolls of filament. They take about an hour to print and only cost a few cents worth of material, however they save me a lot of time, guesswork, and failed prints.

For the temperature gauge, I slice it in Cura using vase/spiralize mode, and set the first couple layers to print at my typical settings. At layer 3, I use Extensions>Post Processing>Modify G-Code>TweakAtZ to lower the nozzle temperature to 180C. At the 10mm height, I use that feature again to raise it to 185C, at 20mm 190C, etc., the rest of the way up the indicator.

After printing I inspect the piece by first attempting to crush the lower end of the column where it has printed colder. Generally it is easy to find the point at which the layers begin to adhere to one one another well; then I look toward the top end of the scale for any signs of overheating. Choosing a print temperature somewhere near the middle of those extremes usually provides me with the best results.

The flowrate scale works in a similar manner, except rather than change the print temperature every 10mm, I simply choose the ideal temp as determined in the previous test, and alter the flowrate as appropriate.

print_settings.Notes:: This should print very quickly and easily on any printer. PLA works well, PETG would probably work better due to increased heat tolerance.

description.text:
I recently installed a MOSFET on my Tarantula and couldn't find a good way to mount it to the vertical rail underneath the mainboard. I whipped this up to allow affixing the MOSFET without attaching it directly to a metal surface. This has two holes at the top and bottom for M4 screws; they should self-tap nicely, and can attach the bracket to any aluminum extrusion with hammer/T-nutes. The MOSFET itself attaches to the posts on the mount with M3 screws, which should also self-tap easily. This gives it a little clearance for airflow and heat dissipation.

This prints quickly out of any material (I would recommend PETG for its heat tolerance and lack of shrinkage, but PLA will probably work too). I hope other people find this useful; I think it bridges the gap between "nothing" and a full enclosure for everything quite nicely.

Please note this is for a standard 60x50 mm MOSFET. I've seen 60x70 mm too; I may make one for that size soon, but this model WILL NOT work with any MOSFET size EXCEPT 60x50 mm.

I noticed with the original that the thin posts could split when the M3 screws are run in. This is a redesign that has thicker posts to better hold these screws. They can still be a bit hard to get in, so I would recommend using a drill if one is available, or otherwise mounting the MOSFET BEFORE installing this bracket on the rail.

description.text: Just a simple Stand for two USB Sticks and SD Cards

Obelisk

This is the most elegant tolerance/fit testing gauge you will ever see.

What's special about it?

It's a one-of-a-kind gauge that relies on a slight taper. This design foregoes the typical binary go and no-go style, and gives us powerful results, easily.

It prints very fast relative to other gauges, requiring very little filament, yet it still gives full range from 0 mm to 1 mm, plus fine decimals!

Never pile up bulky go/no-go tests again.

Technical Specifications

The bottom has a square width of 20mm, and gently tapers to 19 MM over 60 MM.

The ring has a 20 MM inner square width.

How to Print and Use It

Print using a spiralized contour, otherwise known as "vase mode."

To perform the test, the ring is gently slid onto the tower to see how far the ring can travel before stopping.

Measure the distance (in millimeters) left from the bottom of the ring to the bottom of the tower.

Insert this distance for X in 1/60(X)

Or divide 1 by the distance multiplied by 60.

The result should typically be a number between 0.15 and 0.6, which is the amount in MM your printer must be compensated for in your future designs.

Formula

Enter the distance found above, for X and in MM, into the formula below:

1/60(X)

For example, if the bottom of the ring was 20mm away from the bottom of the taper, you would enter 1/60(20)

That would equal 0.33 MM.

Therefore, in order for your printer to produce a ring which fits pristine on a 20mm wide square block, the ring's inner dimension must be designed to be a minimum of 20.33mm, or the block must be reduced to a maximum of 19.67mm.

Tips

  • You can vary the amount of force applied in the experiment to adjust whether the part design you are considering will be a snug or loose fit.

I like to find both a minimum and maximum compensation amount, where the high and low numbers found represent a scale of snug and loose fitting parts possibilities.

  • You can run the test several times and find the average, if you are so inclined.

  • Once you typically fall under a specific clearance, you can cancel the print mid way to save even more filament.

Disclaimer

Creative Commons License - Attribution

I'd love to hear from you. Leave me a message if you have any questions, comments, or suggestions, and I'll get back to you right away.

Thanks, and happy printing,

NPG3D

title: Quad Rover - version 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: 22/12/17 version 2 released, slightly longer core and symetric wheel hubs.
This is my Quad Rover base. It's designed as a platform for a robotic rover to utilise 25mm Gear motors
It can be either remote controlled or fitted with a raspberry pi for remote wifi or autonomous working.
Also provided is a drill guide to drill out the pipe.

The motor tubes are constructed using PVC drainpipe , but if you have the inclination you could print these out as well.

You need to print 4 of the bumpers , which allow the bolts to mount and clamp against the tubing.

4mm bolts are used to connect the front and back to the central core and RC 1/10 wheels are used with 12mm hex adaptors for the motors.

A complete rolling chassis with motors, wheels and mounting bolts only costs about about £50.

for the RC version 2x RC ESC , mixer and battery should only cost about another £20 and then its just the cost of a RC and TX

for the Pi Version a quad motor shield to use is the motozero that only costs £10 on top of a pi Zero Wifi along with a suitable battery and/or a voltage reg for about £3

Parts

M3x6mm Csk bolt - 8 off
M4 Dome nuts - 8 off
M4x8mm Allen Bolts - 4 off
M4 Washer - 12 off
M4x80mm Allen Bolts - 8 off
4 hex wheel hubs

for the radio control version, use 4x 25mm motors @ 6v and 300 rpm
for the raspberry pi, use 4x 25mm motors @12v and 300 rpm

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z8kKNv6Mh20

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5QNwSOp6keI

description.text:
I was looking for a bracket that could hold my headphones off to the side of my desk. I found several on here, but the few I tried were either bulky and wasted filament, or weren't strong - having a lot of flex in the part sliding over the desk/shelf. Decided to try a design that would be strong, yet small, and efficient on filament use.

This supports a thickness of up to 25MM, and handles any headphone with headband up to 50MM. It definitely handles weight, as my heavy pair of headphones (HifiMan He-500) weigh over 1 pound!

description.text:
22mm between standoffs - Will also fit Shendrones Shrieker
Print upside down with supports
Designed to:
1) Not slide down the standoffs
2) Not allow camera to drop below 40ish degrees
3) Allow camera to tilt up as much as possible
4) Be as forward as possible to not have a ton of frame in view and give more room for FC stack
5) Low enough and back enough to not be exposed out of the frame to get damage
6) Minimal weight while sturdy enough to stay in position during lots of crashes.

title: First High Resolution Scan of McDonalds McChicken Sandwich!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Several years ago I had the opportunity to use a high-resolution scanner, and I scanned several hundred random objects; I am now sharing these online.

This is a McDonalds McChicken sandwich. We've all seen and heard that processed food products like this don't really degrade, so I thought, why not try and scan one? The sandwich was left to dry out for several weeks, until hard, then glued together with silicon glue. I had to coat it with primer, since the laser scanner didn't like the chicken, for some reason (Insert your joke here). Unbelievably, it doesn't look any different from the day I purchased it, so it is a perfect replication.

Now you too can own this iconic representation of Fast Food, without breaking your bank account! As far as I know, this is the FIRST High-Resolution scan of a McChicken sandwich! That says something, I think. Yo, McDonalds, PM me....

Please post a photo to share if you print this, and check out my other scans of skulls and bones at http://www.thingiverse.com/dricketts/designs.

Be sure to "Like" my Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/FetalReproductions to subscribe to my current prints/blogs, Follow me on Twitter @Anthrobones, and see my Etsy page at http://Etsy.com/FetalReproductions for baby fetal scans, skulls, and other items to own.

comments.text:
Joe,
No post processing, other than to make it watertight through Meshmixer. This was scanned using a NextEngine laser scanner, at 50 micron resolution. Yes, it is amazingly accurate, it looks just like the original.
comments.author: dricketts

comments.text: What scanner did you use? I take it from the primer you used a structured light device? I'm intrigued by how closed the final model is. did you do any post processing or is this raw?

title: Mounting Clip for Dash Camera Power Cable

description.text:
Update 12/5/17 I added another type of clip that loads from the top, scaled at 10x.

When I added a dash cam to my second car, I found that it was not possible to hide the power cable under the headliner at the top of the windshield. The clips that were furnished with the camera were large and the would be visible at the top of the windshield, so a small clip was needed to complete the installation.

Here is a VERY SMALL clip to support a round power cable anywhere there's a need. The clip is sized for a round cable about 3.4 mm in diameter, but the model can be scaled for a different size cable or longer mounting surface. The cable in the picture is slightly smaller than the one in the car. The coin is a U.S. one cent. You can always terminate the print to shorten the mounting surface. I attached double sided foam tape to the bottom of the clips and trimmed the tape to size with a razor knife.

The .STL file is 10X size, so scale it down to 0.1 for starters, unless you are supporting something larger or smaller. It's a tiny part, so expect some challenges along the way.

The part is designed to print the rounded clip portion with two perimeters @ 0.4 mm wide. If your settings results in a wall that is too thin, maybe I can add another item that will work for you.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I printed this in ABS at 0.2 mm layer height with 2 perimeters using a 0.4 mm nozzle. A 0.3 LH will probably work as well.

Infill:

Enough to make it solid.

Notes:

PLA is likely not suitable for use in a car because of it's low softening temperature.
This is a small part that has a short layer print time. For best results print several at a time so the layer time is long enough that each copy hardens before the next layer is printed. The footprint is also very small, so a brim might be necessary if you have adhesion problems.

Use a round and a flat file to clean up the opening of the clip so the cable can enter without too much deflection of the clip. Use some lubricant like silicon spray on a swab, as needed, applied to the cable to make it easy to roll the cable under the clip.

If there was ever a work in progress, this combine harvester is it. A few hours of work went into this design, and it will likely require a few more. I would love to incorporate parts driven by drive wheels, gears, and chains in later revisions

I would love to hear back from users with what I need change, add etc to make this print better. I know tolerances are too tight on some surfaces, and will likely require some sanding at least to get items to fit. This project will also likely require some glue. I refer to part names by an "American" point of view - passenger side is meant to mean left according to driver (or Port Side).

This machine was very roughly modeled after the John Deere S690 combine (grain) harvester. I don't have one of these at my disposal, so images from the internet are my best reference.

These are an improvement from my previous well received columns. There are 6 designs with 4 inch high and two inch high columns. Columns are influenced by Egyptian, Aztec, and Native American artwork. Also included is a simplistic turning diagonal line, very complex knotted design, and a visual effect provided by patterned lines. Each of the six columns has openlock connections. Also included are 3mm base models without the openlock so you can place them on other types of dungeon designs or tiles. The models with simplistic bases I call top cap and may be abbreviated TC in the file names. OL is for openlock. This is not all. There is also a set of 6 fallen pillar designs that show the pillars split with the upper portion on the ground. There are in effect 30 different designs in this collection with elaborate design work on the columns.

A functional pneumatic plunger to unclog a sink.

How to use:

  • Screw-in the rod into the cylinder.
  • Install the pneumatic cylinder. We want a very tight fit, it will settle after a few movements. Use some candle wax around the cylinder to push it inside. Start with the standard cylinder: CYLINDER 0.0 (standard size). Print only this cylinder first.
  • If it's too tight, print CYLINDER -0.2; it’s a cylinder with 0.2 mm smaller diameter.
  • If that doesn't work, go to CYLINDER -0.3.
  • If the standard cylinder doesn’t fit tightly for some reason, try CYLINDER +0.2 or CYLINDER +0.3.
  • Use an optional skirt for a better suction in some sinks.

Printed at 0.1 mm layer, 20% fill. Supports: NONE. 0.2 mm layer should be OK.

Please see our binary titanium carabiners made from titanium, with the safety gate keeping your keys secure, and the built-in bottle opener, accepted at Amazon.com LaunchPad program.

description.text: This is a Turtle clock that you can print in two forms: slim and thick. I printed it in two colors (you can insert a pause in g-code in the layer where the numbers begin to print and change the filament). I named it "Sandra" because I was promise make it to my sister (who loved the turtles) before she died, but I did can't finished it on time, so this is as a post-mortem gift to she.

Printer:

TronXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.17mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

I printed the main body with PETG and the numbers with ABS. You can insert this gcode to make the filament change (and in my case nozzle temperature too), first locate the z coordinate where the numbers begin to print and in the gcode too, then insert the code:
;-------------------------------
G1 Y190 ;move the bed to front
M104 S228 ;change nozzle temperature (if you change the filament type)
M25 ;pause, to resume select "resume print" in the printer controler screen menu
G28 Y0 ;set Y to home (this is for the printer "touch home" to avoid any...
G28 X0 ;set X to home ... any coordinate decalibration)
G1 X61.130 Y132.247 ; you must put the xy previus immediates coordinates that where in the code to resume correctly
;-------------------------------

description.text:
This is a recreation of an old stage effect used since at least the mid 1500's (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Column_wave). Made mostly as just a desk toy, like a conversation grinder. To see the effect look down the side.

The waves are placed in order by how many times they revolve and turned by a crank.

You will need some 8x M3 screws to mount the wave columns to the frame, as well as 6x Bearings (623 Z 3x10x4 mm 623Z Ball Bearings 623ZZ RepRap) to make sure they turn smoothly.

Special thanks to the Museum of Jurassic Technology (http://www.mjt.org/) where I first saw this in an exhibit. Also thanks to whoever made GearGenerator.Com which made adding gears possible.

description.text:
The macroline fittings on the stock replicator extruder bracket began to weaken and flex. (see picture of my stock part.) This caused an annoying creaking noise, and also weakened the filament within the macroline feed tube. This eventually caused the filament to mis-feed and even fracture.
So, I took the .stl file from the replicator build files and shrunk the holes down to accept paintball style macroline fittings. These fittings are much beefier and thread in through the full thickness of the extruder bracket. This should create a stronger and more durable connection that will last.
I also had to move the holes about 1/10 inch back from the front of the machine to center the holes over the extruder entry holes. The stock macroline connectors have a much looser tolerance so they can stand to be slightly off center. Whereas my macroline fittings need to be better centered to work.
Added benefit? You can choose any color you like to print this in! :)

1 - Order some straight macroline fittings from your supplier of choice. These are easily found online at paintball suppliers. I got mine from ANSgear.com for about $10USD shipped to my door.
( https://www.ansgear.com/ProductDetails.asp?ProductCode=MACROFITTINGSTRAIGHT )
You are going to need 2 of these, since this part is for the dualstrusion replicator. 2 - Download the .stl file from this thing :) 3 - Print out using THREE shells. The macroline fittings will be cutting their own threads into the part when you screw them in. I used 10% fill, but that number isn't quite so important with so many shells on a thin part. 4 - carefully clean out the 2 smaller holes that the screws thread through. I didn't worry so much about the exact size. I believe they are m3 screws, but I just picked a close drill bit from my collection and spun it in the hole carefully till the screws threaded in comfortably. 5 - carefully thread both of your fittings into the part. Be sure that they are going in perpendicular to the part. This is merely aesthetic since the filament will be able to handle a slight angle. But why not make it look pretty if you can? :) 6 - re-install on your machine just like you un-installed the stock part. Note, I also have installed on my machine the wire bundle strain releiever part. (Thing link: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21570 ) So don't be confused about that other natural colored ABS part sticking up from the extruder bracket.

comments.text: FWIW, I've seen two Replicator 1's for which the holes on this part need to be moved FORWARD about 0.1 inch. Â So, while some Replicator 1's may have needed the holes moved back about 0.1 inch, others seem to need it left as is (not moved back).

title: Bearing Block for 23.5mm Conduit with 608 Bearings and SM8UU Mounting Holes

description.text: You gotta check out the y axis bearing guide thing that slides on conduit. I designed that to replace a sm8uu bearing and uses standard 608 bearings. It has 18mm by 24mm hole spacing so it should just attach to any build plate mount. The more I think about this part the more my mind tries to apply it to other ideas. My hope is to eliminate all the smooth rods and use conduit instead. I know the print quality is diminished in the end but lets face it no matter what parts always look "3d printed" anyways so just use cheap conduit. The longer you use the machine the better the print quality becomes as the machine breaks in the conduit and makes a smooth spot.

description.text:
Follow and revisit this page for latest design!!!! An ongoing design with the end goal to be a good working DIY wind turbine. I have never made one, drawing and experimenting from info online. Updates are coming with trail and error over time. PLS. Comment with any improvement you can think of =). Republished due to a bug in the old thingpage. (sorry all who had it in lists.) Soildworks files are included if you want to redesign something. Knows issues, and hopefully coming improvement:
YOU ARE WERY WELCOME TO HELP WITH THE DESIGN OR ISSUES
-Pole mount with rotation connection for wiring is missing.
-Make the design waterproof
-Alternator house needs a mount for a ball bearing closer to the turbine.
-No design on a "tail wing" so it follows the wind around.
-Housing parts are hard to print the design is warping happy.
-To tight fit here and there.
-Blades are a random design with no what so ever calculation or aerodynamic knowledge behind.
-Missing a sharp nice looking nose cone for the turbine.
-The housing is not possible to fit together the nuts needed to tighten is inside LOL Updates/Log:
20140403 Massive uppdate
-Changed from a 1phase to a 3phase design. 12 magnets and 9 coils. (stratorcoils and frame, rotors both, and middistance uppdated.) -10mm thick magnets instead of 3mm.(rotors uppdated) -3 mm thicker stratorframe, more space to roll coils. Possible now with thicker magnets. (frame, coils and distance updated) -moved coils yet a bit towards center for better room for the copper.(colis and rotors updated) -made the 0.4 walls holding magnets to 0.6.(rotors updated) -Made the outside diamter of rotors smaller to save some rotating mass. (rotors updated) 20140329
-Design error found canât putt lid and wall together and after that tighten the nuts inside! Well driving it without for now needs a new design in the future tho.
-probably needs other types of bearings for forward and backward force. donât know model name though.
-Heads-up, Iâm switching to 10mm thick magnets!! So redesign for it coming.
http://www.supermagnete.de/eng/S-20-10-N 20140328
-Distance rings for bearings. 20140323
-Front support added some support and anti-warping. 20140320 parts for mounting on a pole not complete
-Pole mount mountingpeg v1,
-Pole mount upper plate v1
-Baseplate v4 holes and stuff for pole mount. 20140318
-Baseplate v3 adjusted hole size for better fitting for bearing, added anti warping thingies.
  • Found this http://www.ebay.com/itm/181330029893 so new design plan, more simple than before.
    • 20140317
    -Pen and paper.. sitting here and drawing on different solutions for the turning mount... so nothing to show digital. The plan is rings from 22mm copper water pipe and coal from a car alternator some model that are spread around the world. As always all the parts should be possible to obtain or make with tools found in every home. 20140316
    -Moved colis and magnets 3mm closer to centrum the coil wire in the new v2 config didnât fit. So now Coils v3 and rotors v4. Did also make the rotors 10mm smaller diameter less waste print. 20140314
    -Coils V2. Made bigger centercore for coils, did read somewhere that the inner width of coils should be the same as the magnets width. Anyone know how it really should be? 20140313
    -Front support v1. Added a front support with place for a bearing close to the blade hub.
    -Backplate V3, Anti warping thingies. New holes for future backswing. Removed holder for backwings and moved bearing inside so it can be printed with the big surface flat on printerbed. Oversized the bearing hole with 0.4 for better fitting.

For your Information about the non-upright positioning in Thingiverse:
Solidworks uses the y-axis as the upright one, STL-Files and 3D printers normally use the z-axis as the upright axis.
When I Started with Autodesk Fusion360, I had the same problem until I figured out that you can change the upright axis from y into z. Idk if that works for Solidworks too but you can check that in the Settings.
I hope I could help you with that Problem.

description.text:
This is a x axis belt tensioner, super simple cam design... mounted to the x extrusion using the extra m4 t nut and one of the extra m4 screws that came with the cr-10.... this helps tremendously when tensioning the x axis belt..

loosen the x axis pulley assembly slightly, install the tensioner so its at one of the lower settings... lightly but firmly pull the x axis pulley assembly and start to advance the tensioner cam until you have the proper tension on the belt... you will get to a point where you can not advance the cam to the next notch... at this point the tensioner cam will hold the tension on the belt, simply tighten the pulley assembly and your done... the tensioner assembly can now be removed...

this is made as a tool to assist in the tensioning process, it CANNOT be left on the extrusion.. your extruder will crash into the assembly at around 270mm and above if left on... this isn't an issue if your printing models smaller than that... you decide..

hope this can be useful

maker select v2 / CR-10

author: bubalettow

description.text:
Perhaps one of my greatest designs yet - this is the one that I'll be remembered for when I die. No, I don't mind that this will be the case. Better people have been and will be remembered for lesser things. :)

Anyways, this is a narrower version of the Swiffer that allows you to reach those difficult to access areas around kitchen appliances and other nooks/crannies. It allows you to recycle your old dryer sheets which work pretty well at sweeping up dust and gunk that collects on the floor. Use binder clips to secure the sheets and a self-adhesive foam surface on the bottom of the mopper to help it glide extra smooth across your classy faux-wood floor.

Dampen a paper towel to make it into a bonfied wet mop. Oh the joy.

Here's a 2 minute video of the assembly and usage cuz I know you wanna do it right:
https://youtu.be/XiUh5KDb28g

Except for the handlejoint, all of the .stl files should be printed as is without support. The handlejoint just needs external support only. Their print orientations are important for good structural integrity during use.

If you found this useful, it would bring me great joy to see your work - so be sure to share. :)

Or, better yet, please feel free to dump a bitcoin or two here (I'm trying to collect as many as I can before the apocalypse):

1Py3TUeR8noBN2giHyFV1GfB6x3Kh2WEVv

... include a note to the effect of "Hi 3E8, thanks for the kitchen mopper thing... my life is infinitely better on account of it and please accept this paltry amount in gratitude".

You're welcome! (in advance) :D

Also, feel free to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is an acrylic case for a Amiga 500. Specially made for the Capacitor Party, an Amiga party at Málaga City in Spain. This case allows to use an A500 motherboard (in my case, a1k A500 edition) which I don't have a special case for it, that's why I designed it.

This A500 have:

A1k motherboard
Vampire 500 v2
Internal speaker using an Pam amplifier.
Hdmi
Lan via SDNET
Gotek OLED and Gotek buttons and usb on the lateral.
Mechanical keyboard.

If you want to use your a500 keyboard, you will need to redesign the front panel of the keyboard, since this panel is made for a AUKEY mechanical keyboard. Also a keyboard support at bottom will be required (designed), but depends of your keyboard angle.

This case must be cutted on a 3mm acrylic / methacrylate. Also a few 3x10mm screws with nuts required to assembly.

The company that I use to cut the case is TransparentCity, they are very cheap and the finish are high quality.

Contact: [email protected]

Note: This case is a preliminary design, the design works because I fully assembled it but maybe a few modifications is required if others devices are plugged into the A500.

I designed this lamp to run off my 3D printer's power supply. It has pan, tilt and height adjustments. The lamp uses 12 volt power, or with different parts it can be 24 volt. Nominal power consumption is 3.6 watts. The power can be changed by using a different resistor, but be careful of overheating. Assembling this lamp requires soldering.

The LED gets hot, so at least the lamp casing should be printed with a high temperature filament. The diffuser should be printed with transparent filament.

The pieces mostly snap or screw together, but the pegs on the side of the lamp must be glued on.

Bill of Materials

  • Cree CXA1304 series LED, 9 volt: Choose an LED with your preferred color temperature. For 24 volts, use an 18 volt LED.
  • 10 Ohm 2 Watt Resistor: For 24 volts, use a 39 ohm resistor. When assembled, the resistor goes inside the tube.
  • Aavid Thermalloy Heat Sink 507002B00000G
  • Thermal Grease: Use any suitable thermal grease.
  • Power Switch: Use any suitable power switch. I have included a printable case for the linked switch.
  • Wires: Use any wires of similar size.
  • Power Connectors: I used these barrel jacks and this barrel plug to connect the lamp to my printer. I have included a housing that holds two of the linked jacks, the lid of it is designed to be welded on with a 3D pen or you can or you could glue it on.

title: Ferret Trinket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I came across u/lumpytuna's laser-cut ferret pendant on Reddit and thought, "I could print that!" So I did.

Just in time for holiday decor and gift giving season.

(With permission) I made this version by re-tracing the image in u/lumpytuna's post as a vector, then extruded the two colors proportionally for printing. For the best results at any scale, I ended up with three slightly different versions with varying amounts of detail in the face. All are roughly 100mm tall by default.

  • The simple version (Simple_Ferret.stl) is ideal for printing at any scale, big or small, and recommended for most cases.
  • The medium version (Medium_Ferret.stl) is similar to the previous, but with more geometry in the eyes and mouth.
  • The detailed version (Detailed_Ferret.stl) is closest to the original laser-cut design, but unless you have a very small nozzle (<0.3) OR intend to scale it up greater than 150%, the face may turn messy.

u/lumpytuna's original ferret pendant necklace can be found here: https://obscenerie.com/collections/the-menagerie/products/ferret-pendant

Supports:

No

Notes:

Regardless of which version you print, choose a smaller-than-usual extrusion width for your nozzle if you can. This will allow you to resolve more detail in the face. Smaller layer heights will also reduce unsightly blobs or banding on the top layers.

For dual-color printing (like seen above) on a mono-color printer, pause your print during any of the last few layers and swap filaments. Alternatively, you may be able to feed in a new color towards the end of the print without pausing.

title: Dell Laptop Power Adapter Cord Wrap

description.text:
I bought a Dell Latitude Business laptop and it didn't have much in terms of cable management such as velcro straps, etc. I got sick of tangled cords and the power adapter kept getting caught on everything while trying to pull it from the bag.

This cable wrap is for the Dell Slim Power Adapter 65w and 90w models. The adapters came with Dell Latitudes in the past couple years and they have rounded sides (see images). It may fit other adapters that share the same shape, as long as the width of (rounded side to other rounded side) is 66.5mm and the thickness is 22.5mm.

http://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/accessories/apd/492-bbom?ref=p13n_ena_pdp_vv&c=us&cs=04&l=en&s=bsd

http://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/accessories/apd/332-1833?ref=p13n_ena_pdp_vv&c=us&cs=04&l=en&s=bsd

Dell made several power adapters similar to these in design. Feel free to re-mix the design idea as necessary to fit your adapter.

I created it in 2 parts. This resulted in parts that do not need supports to print. This also left much of the rest of the adapter exposed to facilitate heat dissipation. The posts are curved and have beveled edges in some places to prevent unnecessary wear on the wiring.

Assembly:
The pieces are friction fit and include a small lip to prevent them sliding towards each other when you start wrapping. If you print with less tolerance, they may not be as snug. If your's print and they are too loose, or if you simply want some insurance to stay on, each piece has a small channel to run zip-ties through. Depending on the size of the zip ties you use, you may need to daisy chain several of them together. I used a total of 6, 140mm long zip ties, 3 chained together on each side.

Please note: the 2 pieces are slightly different. The piece with the notch cut out is intended for the side where the cable that plugs into the laptop resides. This file is labeled as the "DC side". The file labeled as the "AC side" is intended for the side where the 3-prong plug resides that goes into the wall. There are 3 files: AC side, DC side, and the third file includes both. I include all 3 files in case some people only want to print one at a time or have smaller print beds.

To use:
First wrap the wall plug (AC) lengthwise around the adapter, using the groove between the posts to hold it in position. Then start wrapping the cable around the posts.

Second, take the laptop plug (DC) and wrap it around the smaller posts on the side. You can use any remaining slack to wrap around the entire unit horizontally to hold the other cable in place.

You can also add a large rubber band or velcro strap to help facilitate holding it together.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

I used 10% infill with honeycomb pattern to give it strength while using less filament. The part is plenty strong without needing to use extra filament on infill. Feel free to adjust resolution and infill to fit your needs. The part is not precise enough to warrant any extra care.

I printed mine in PLA. My power adapter doesn't get warm with normal use and I have not experienced any warping with mine. However, if your adapter gets hot often you may consider printing this part in filament that is more tolerant to heat such as PETG or ABS.

The adapter itself. Wrapping the cable like this is time consuming. It also means you still have to wrap the AC cable separately. My design allows you to quickly wrap both parts of the cable in a nice tidy bundle. Post print. Special notch on DC side for cable. All wrapped up tidy.

TinkerCAD

title: Miniature takedown recurve bow
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A miniature takedown recurve bow. Intended as a toy and for fun, however, it functions the same as a proper bow - do not point or shoot at any living being.

This is a WIP.

Additionally you will need:
4 x M4 bolts
4 x M4 nuts or wingnuts.
Some fishing line to be woven or other string that's not elastic.
Some bamboo skewers (wrap some electrical tape near the tips for weight and better flight and make some "feathers" on the back)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low

Notes:

Print the limbs with as much of perimeters (walls) as you can. This will help the limbs bend gradually.

Print the regular handle file with high infill percentage (50-100%). However, if you have a tough non-flexible material, you can try printing with 0 bottom and top layers and 15-30% honeycomb infill for an interesting look.

Print the shell handle if you want to pour polyester (or some other) resin inside.

These are the files for my Candy Cane Christmas Tree,

Version 1 - this one has a Larger Gap between the 2 sections. meaning that it can be printed with Larger Layer Hights, and when printed at 0.2mm Layer Heights can be dropped together

Both Versions can be printed with Zero Infill and with No Supports

Enjoy Playing with these Files

Merry Christmas

I got tired of my Printrbot LC+ sliding all over my desk, so I made these feet.
You'll just need some of those stick on rubber pads and you're all set.  It's a tight fit, but you may or may not want to use the mounting holes.  You'd have to drill the plywood.

comments.text: @ k1nc81d, thanks, I must have searched for Printerbot LC+ when I was looking to see if anyone else had done this.  Yea, it does look like the LC+ has a thicker foot than the LC.  I'm still dialing in my bot, so some of the feet fit snug and others didn't.  I broke the idler during assembly, and I think it gave up the ghost on this print.  Lucky, I printed a spare!
comments.author: RockstarAlchemist

comments.text: I made some a while back for the standard LC, it looks like the plus is double wide, but found that no drilling was necessary.  A snug fit is all that is needed.

remixed_from.author: fgebhart
remixed_from.title: Hovering Disk - DIY 3D Printed - Frictionless Motion Experiment

title: Hovering Disk For Less Perfect Surface- Frictionless Motion Experiment
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a Remix of fgebharts hovering disk. I found his version didn't work for me. Disk didnt lift much and movement was anything but frictionless. This was probably because bottom of my print and the surface I wanted hover on (table, floor) were not perfectly smooth. Nozzle of the original is very narrow which increases the duration of hovering, but it decreases the airflow and therefore requires better surface to slide across. So in order to make it work in normal classroom conditions I made the nozzle wider. I also moved the rim that holds the balloon lower so that its neck is better supported. This makes the balloon more stable therefore helping it from breaking its neck and tiping to a side.

title: Quiz / Arcade Button buzzer WITH LED

description.text:
I printed this to use with the quizz button design for arduino. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1011725

Video working (please dont laught, I was also holding the mobile XD):
https://drive.google.com/open?id=1jJa1PkC_Y-ynoNP73kR06RgzW6R-u-eD

I wanted big buttons, but they where too expensive, so I dessigned this big buttons to fit my needs.
Also, I wanted the player button to get iluminated also, so I replaced the resistance for a second LED, and also replaced the RCA connectors (2 ways/cables: GRN+BUTTON) for Stereo Jack connectors (3 ways/cables: GRN+BUTTON+LED). Doing that i was able to use simple AUX (Jack to Jack) cables to connect the players quizz buttons, and also insert the second LED inside the button mechanism

If you want to build it and have some doubts, just ask ;)

comments.text:
Hello, thank you for your design is exactly what I am looking for.
Do you use the same switches? How to fix Stereo Jack connectors?
Would it be possible to take a picture of the inside of the buzzers?
Best regards.
comments.author: wreckedhopes

comments.text: Thanks for your comment. I'll try to make a scheme of the circuit, and also take new pictures. Inside the button is the same push button that is used in the central controller.
comments.author: wreckedhopes

remixed_from.title: Easy Spool Holder - Spool Safety Lock (Prusa MK2 / MK2S / MK3)

title: Easy Spool Holder - Spool Safety Lock with Stoppers (Prusa MK2 / MK2S)

description.text:
Petclaud did a great job remixing IsmaelPR1's spool holder and even included a spool lock. I wanted to use the spool lock for the cardboard spools because I'm always worried they'll fall over. Unfortunately his is too short for my spools so I made a longer version. I also added some holes to place a stopper that limits the spool's travel and prevents it from falling over.

IsmaelPR1's spool holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1768975
Petclaud's remix: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2661364

title: AnyCubic Kossel Linear Plus V-Rail mod plus corner cover

description.text:
This AnyCubic Linear Plus mod is in response to the very poor operational properties of the supplied linear glide rails that they provide. I have replaced the vertical member with true V-Rail from Openbuilds.com, and used the wheels and eccentrics from the same source. The carriage (shown in white) is a custom design, and is dimensionally equivalent to the linear glide in all ways that matter. The performance has been stellar.

Also included is a remix of a corner cover that keeps glue, plastic and any other trash off the motors and the internals of the printer.

Solidworks models are available for both custom parts.

Use 80% fill for the carriage, anything you like for the cover plates.

comments.text: Which wheels and bolts and spacers did you use? Mini-V or regular wheels? Are all the spacers excentric? What length bolt and which locknuts to choose? I would like to upgrade my Kossel in this manner, but I find it difficult to know which items I need to purchase.
comments.author: pipme

comments.text: Hi there, happy to help.  The wheels are in fact the standard Mini-V kit with low profile 25mm m5 screws and nylock-style nuts.  There are two wheels with 6mm non-eccentric spacers on one side of the V-Rail, and one wheel with a 6mm eccentric on the other.  You must use the eccentric that is designed for the Mini-V wheels, the larger one (for the big wheel) won't fit. Don't forget to put the precision 1mm washer inside the wheel between the bearings or the bearings will fail.  I can post assembly pictures if it would help.  Good luck!

title: PS4 Pro vertical stand with vibration dampening

description.text:
As you already know from the title, this is an vertical stand for the PS4 Pro. What's special about this one is, that it has some vibration dampening balls. If you put a disc in your PS4, then you may be lucky and your PS4 stays silent. But if you are like me and always get the bad ones, then your PS4 will create some nasty vibrations. Those vibrations transfer onto the table/closet/"or whatever your PS4 is standing on" and increase the noise even more.

That's where the vibration dampening gets interesting. The dampening balls prevent the vibrations to transfer onto "the thing" that your PS4 is standing on. So no more annoying noises due to the vibrations. Even my PS4 is barely audible now (except for the fans and the motor of the drive).

The vibration dampening balls are commonly used on camera gimbals. I tried some different types (Tarot, Arris, Hobbyking...) and they all worked. You just need to make sure, that the complete set of vibration dampening balls isn't too soft. I went for 900 g on each stand (2x 300 g on the outside, 2x 150 g at the center). There a several mounting positions for the balls. 1200 g should also work.

I did print it from PLA and it works just fine. So ABS and PETG should work aswell.

Rubber_dampening.STEP/.STL added. If you want to design your own printable dampening balls, you can use the dimensions of the STEP file.

Vibration dampening balls:
300 g - https://hobbyking.com/de_de/vibration-damping-balls-300g-red-8-pcs.html
200 g - https://hobbyking.com/de_de/vibration-damping-balls-200g-yellow-8-pcs.html
150 g - https://hobbyking.com/de_de/vibration-damping-balls-150g-blue-8-pcs.html

=== german description ===

Wie der Titel schon sagt, handelt es sich hierbei um einen Halter für die PS4 Pro, um diese vertikal hinzustellen. Das Besondere an der Halterung ist, dass sie eine Dämpfung besitzt. Wenn man eine Disc in die PS4 einlegt, dann kann man Glück haben und die PS4 summt leise vor sich hin. Wenn man aber - wie ich - vom Pech verfolgt ist, dann hat man eine PS4 erwischt, die sehr stark vibriert. Diese Vibrationen können sich auf den Tisch/Schrank/"oder worauf auch immer die PS4 steht" übertragen und so laute, unangenehme Geräusche verursachen (bei mir: tiefes Brummen).

An der Stelle wird die Dämpfung interessant. Die Dämpfung verhindert, dass sich die Vibrationen auf den Untergrund übertragen können. Also keine unangenehmen Geräusche durch die Vibrationen mehr. Sogar meine PS4 ist jetzt angenehm leise. Man hört nur noch die Lüfter und den Motor vom Laufwerk.

Die Dämpfer werden üblicherweise bei Kamera-Gimbals eingesetzt. Ich habe verschiedene Typen durchprobiert (Tarot, Arris, Hobbyking...) und alle haben funktioniert. Man muss nur darauf achten, dass das komplette Set nicht zu weich ist. Ich bin auf 900 g gegangen (2x 300 g außen, 2x 150 g in der Mitte). Es gibt diverse Montagepunkte für die Dämpfer, man kann da also ein bisschen variieren. 1200 g sollte auch funktionieren.

Gedruckt habe ich den Halter aus PLA und das hält wunderbar. ABS und PETG sollten also auch kein Problem sein.

Rubber_dampening.STEP/.STL hinzugefügt. Dabei handelt es sich um ein Modell der Hobbyking Dämpfer. Daran kann man sich orientieren, wenn man selber Dämpfer für den 3D Druck erstellen möchte.

Dämpfer:
300 g - https://hobbyking.com/de_de/vibration-damping-balls-300g-red-8-pcs.html
200 g - https://hobbyking.com/de_de/vibration-damping-balls-200g-yellow-8-pcs.html
150 g - https://hobbyking.com/de_de/vibration-damping-balls-150g-blue-8-pcs.html

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2 MMU

No

No

20 %

author: DCP

description.text:
So for months I have avoided my Perception Neuron suit. It hasn't performed well due to 4 Neurons being weird and faulty. So today I bit the bullet and grabbed my prop connector and Individually tested and updated all 18 of my Neurons. After an hour or so of testing, updating, more testing I finally was able to Find the Neurons that have been the bane of my existence. But that's not the point of this story today. This post has to do with the god awful pain I received from removing the Neurons over and over again 50+ times. I'm a nail bitter, so I really have no length to my fingernails, so when it came to removing these Neurons so often I was dying from the pain. There were points where I had my girlfriend who has nails try to remove the Neurons and if was still really hard for her.

I like that the Neurons are hard to get out. Snugg fit, I get it. But DAMN... My thumb is still throbbing hours later. So I decided to fix the problem....

I grabbed the dimensions of a Neuron, Tossed it into Maya and 3D modeled a Pry tool for the Neurons. After 4 iterations and testing I was finally able to print out a working (And pretty neat looking) Pry tool. But I figured that with a whole community on these forums I should share what I made to ease others lives..

Here is the link to my design - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2688363

In less than 20 minutes I was able to print this out on my Mono Price mini v1 at %100 Infill. Its pretty sturdy but I decided to print 4 more just encase NOW ILL NEVER DAMAGE MY THUMBS AGAIN! Hopefully... Ill keep the Thingiverse page updated with any future iterations I create.

If you do not own a 3D printer I suggest clicking the “Order this printed” Option, it will take the print and you with it to a page that will setup a purchasing option for you. I WILL NOT GAIN ANY MONEY FROM YOUR PURCHASE THAT I KNOW OF . When I tested this option I found that there is a $9 fee for shipping and printer setup and that the piece itself was only $0.45 WHAT A RIP OFF! Soooooo Since the print is so cheap I would recommend ordering more than 1 or 2, just to offset to Shipping and labor price. I could buy 1 pry tool for $9.45 or 12 for $14.40 so for just 5 dollars more you get 12 pry tools. Hell for $22.50 you can buy 30 pry tools and mail them in a standard envelope to other forum users I DONT KNOW ITS YOUR MONEY.

I hope you enjoy this tool, I hope Noitom and the Perception Neuron team include pry tools in their cases in the future. But until then I hope this serves you well.

QUICK TIP! - While I was testing my Neurons I decided to cut little squares of green masking tape and label the top of each Neuron with numbers. This way I can track what Neurons are giving me issues and keep tack of their history.

Infill:

%100

author: kaufi

description.text:
These two styles of belt clip were hastily designed to replace a broken clip on a portable radio scanner I was tasked to repair.
Sadly I did not have time to take photos as it was a rush job.

However the model is a realistic Pro-37 - they are quite vintage now, and parts are impossible to get.

There are two styles of clip, one suited to the original factory screws and one suited to 3mm machine screws.
